title: Government announces £1 billion plan to end countryside mobile 'notspots'
text:
The end of mobile 'not spots' is in sight as the Government announced a plan to boost mobile internet signal in the countryside.

Culture Secretary Nicky Morgan said a £1 billion plan had been agreed in principle between the Government and four major mobile providers to achieve 95 percent coverage of the UK by 2025.

Under the plan, EE, O2, Three and Vodafone will spend £530 million on a scheme to share masts so all customers will be able to get 4G coverage in areas where only one of a few of the providers has reception.

The Government has then pledged £500 million to build masts in remote areas with no coverage and to open up its own network, which is used by the emergency services, to extend 4G reception.

Currently, around a third of the UK has patchy or no mobile coverage.
